Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 9138c209c796ea49edf73d6039b6644ce32c959c
Please be specific to the planned change
Description looks wrong and dbus time out has no connection to PLDM retry.
this is done with reference to the previous timeout entry here . I can change it if required in next reviews
What is difference between response-time-out and dbus_timeout_value?

Modified the comment for this in the newer patchsets. Dbus timeout is used for bus.call only. we have defined timeout value for all dbus calls as 5 seconds so that bus.call exists after 5 seconds if there is no response from other end
We do not need any change here
timeout is equal response-time-out, why we need new option?
we dont need a change in for retrytimer. This has been removed in the latest patchsets
bus.call ? this is code or a function name ? not the right thing to be included inside the commit message.
you commit message should answer following questions mentioned in https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages

why do you wanna pass this a parameter ? 

can we just use the DBUS_TIMEOUT directly in this function after including the config.h ? 

What is the reason for taking a new argument ?
redundant variable ? directly use the DBUS_TIMEOUT ? or reduce the scope of this variable.
make the option name consistent with other options, none of the meson options have _, they have -

what is min 500 here mean ? and max is 20000 ? 

500 milli seconds ? seconds ? hours ? can you add this info as well
this is ibm specific , please remove it
this is IBM term, please remove it.
add a new line before this.
Varsha you could change "Testing" to  something like "Tested By"
if you change option to seconds, then you dont need to do any conversion to seconds anywhere else in the code. you can directly use the value it self right ?
instead make the option seconds, and you dont need this conversion everywhere.
Changes looks good to me , just a small change needed in the option readme.

There is no retry on dbus.

you can rephrase this as :

The amount of time pldm waits to get a response for a dbus message before timing out.

The time out is being considered as useconds, so 5 is being considered as 5 useconds, we need to consider 5 as 5 seconds.

virtual int sd_bus_call(sd_bus* bus, sd_bus_message* m, uint64_t usec,

please re-work on the code.

How was this tested?

`Tested by adding a sleep for 10 seconds inside main function of
phospher-host-postd and executed get dbus property on snoopd. PLDM
dbus call timed out after 5 seconds.`

This was initially tested with normal IPL and re-ipl and the bad path was tested with a getdbus property that timed out in 5 seconds . after some review comments we removed the conversion 
std::chrono::microseconds timeout = std::chrono::microseconds(DBUS_TIMEOUT); and directly sent DBUS_TIMEOUT value to bus.call . This was not retested with IPLs. Since bus.call considers time in micro seconds and not in seconds we sent timeout as 5usecs. before merge when this was tested we could not IPL because the pldmd timed out too quickly. 

I have made corrections and added the coversions back and retested . Test details are added on the commit message

yes - we could make the default as systemd's default.

As a standard pldm instance id expiration time is max 5 seconds, if we have the timeout of dbus as 25seconds, we are always bound to respond after 25seconds and that will not be useful as the remote terminus requests and retries would be completed in the first 5 seconds of the 25seconds.

Agree that this would not fix the entire issue, but this would make this worse in bad situations.

Not sure if there is a timing spec for dbus, but we felt 3 seconds would be a reasonable time for a daemon to respond for a dbus message[provided the daemon is running on a bmc that has very less computation resources and is busy].

If needed we could default this to systemd default ,and over ride that via meta-ibm layer if needed. What do you think is the best way forward ?

> @Manoj as a side topic, we should consider introducing async D-Bus client calls for cases, where we don't want PLDM daemon to be help up for long running operations.

Yes, we started to work on some prototypes to make things async, but it seems like a pretty big infrastructure change and its gonna take time. We can have this meson option removed once we have the async infrastructure change in.
Haging for 5 seconds is atleast better than hanging for 25 seconds :)
The instance ID expiration time of 5-6 secs is a good rationale to have a D-Bus timeout of 5 sec.
Please cleanup all blank line changes.
I belive the new lines are being added because of the latest clang.
Change looks fine now. If you are able to test positive and negative paths we are good.

I still dont like the meson option to have values like 30Lakhs, and let's be consistent in meson options..all the other meson options are in seconds, so lets have this also in seconds. and do the conversion required in the code.

i dont think we need this conversion everywhere. instead we can remove these two lines. and instead of timeout.count() in the bus.call() ..we can replace that with 
```
bus.call(mapper,std::chrono::duration_cast<std::chrono::microseconds>(std::chrono::seconds(DBUS_TIMEOUT)).count())
```

and this can be further reduced, if you include the chrono namespace, it will be as simple as 

```
bus.call(mapper, duration_cast<microseconds>(seconds(DBUS_TIMEOUT)).count())
```
